awd_titl_txt: Timing and Paleoceanographic Impacts of the Onset of Arctic-Baffin Bay Throughflow
awd_abstract_narration:
Changes in the amount of sea ice and low salinity surface water (together called freshwater) that flow from the Arctic Ocean to the North Atlantic have global ocean circulation and climate impacts.  The research involves analysis of the timing and consequences of the opening of the western route for Arctic freshwater flux after the retreat of glacier ice at the end of the last glaciation. The Arctic freshwater flows through the western route to the Labrador Sea, which is a critical area of deep ocean convection.  Diverse analyses of sediment cores from northern Baffin Bay and computer modeling will be used to document and explore the large changes in sea-ice cover, Arctic freshwater flux, ocean circulation, marine productivity, and ocean acidification over the last 11,000 years that are associated with opening of the western freshwater route.  An important component of the research is to study the history of the North Water Polynya (NOW), an oasis of high productivity and low sea-ice cover that forms where the Arctic freshwater enters northern Baffin Bay. The productivity of the NOW owes to the high nutrient content of the Arctic freshwater and to the blockage of Arctic sea-ice floes by the constricted channels forming the gateway.  The NOW is a hotspot of biological productivity that has attracted humans to the area for millennia and sustains Arctic communities today. Both the history of freshwater flux via the western freshwater route and the history of the NOW are very poorly known, yet the behavior of this system is poised to change in response to continuing reductions in Arctic sea-ice cover. The understanding of how the opening of the western route of Arctic freshwater and the initiation of the NOW have changed through time will provide context to understand how these systems will affect the Arctic systems and global climate in future.

The project uses existing sediment cores from the NOW polynya, and areas upstream of and downstream from it using both novel (nutrient tracers from Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry and algal biomarkers) and traditional (quantitative X-ray mineralogy, foraminiferal assemblages, stable C and O isotopes) proxies, climate modeling with the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and Glacial Isostatic Adjustment modeling and chronology development (radiocarbon and paleomagnetic secular variation) to test three hypotheses: Hypothesis 1: The opening of the western freshwater route of the Arctic-Atlantic throughflow changed the freshwater outflow to the North Atlantic with consequences for the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC). Hypothesis 2: Significant shallowing of the CAA channels by glacial isostatic uplift has changed the composition of the Arctic outflow with consequences for carbonate preservation and the AMOC.  Hypothesis 3: The NOW formed in the middle to late Holocene as a consequence of increased Arctic sea-ice. The project is an international effort involving Canadian and EU cooperation and foreign graduate student interaction with CU faculty and scientists.  It will provide support and mentoring for a female post-doc who will receive training in novel biogeochemical laboratory techniques.  A PhD student will work on the CESM modeling. Several undergraduate students will receive training and participate in the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Arctic is warming rapidly in response to modern climate change with consequences for the the stability of the cryosphere (e.g. glaciers and sea ice), global sea level, and for maintenance of Arctic ecosystems. Changes in the volume and pathways of freshwater flux by glacier melt and sea-ice export from the Arctic into the North Atlantic via channels within the Canadian Arctic Archipelago can impact the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), an important oceanic governor of climate through its role in distribution of heat from low to high latitudes. The study area is northern Baffin Bay, immediately south of the channel mouths where today, Arctic Surface Water (ASW) enters Baffin Bay, a northern arm of the North Atlantic Ocean. The North Water Polynya (NOW or Pikialasorsuaq) forms at the channel mouths and augments the marine productivity in the region. A polynya is an area of thin or absent sea ice surrounded by much thicker and higher concentration sea ice, like an oasis of open water in a desert of sea ice. The high primary productivity of polynyas supports Arctic ecosystems from primary producers through to humans. Innuit communities are concentrated around the NOW in response to these rich resources. The future existence of the NOW is thus important on many levels. At the start of our project it was thought that sea ice arches (essentially plugs of sea ice that block the export of mutli year sea ice through Nares Strait) were essential for the formation of the polynya. Ice arch formation has become unreliable leading to greater multi-year sea ice loss from the Arctic Ocean, yet the polynya persists due to other factors such as strong northernly winds.

 

The overall goal of this project was to reconstruct the history of the western freshwater route for Arctic to Atlantic water flow from deglaciation onward using sediment cores and modeling, and to test the impacts of freshwater flow through these channels on the AMOC and on the formation of the NOW. The study area has undergone profound physiographic and climate changes over the last 20,000 years, and study of the responses of this area to major climage changes of the past increases the scope and provides case studies for understanding the influence of sea ice and channel status on the NOW. Our sediment core studies have defined the timing and consequences of several phases in this development, beginning with complete blockage of the channels by large confluent ice sheets at the Last Glacial Maximum (~20,000 years ago), to opening first of Parry Channel by deglaciation (10,600 years ago), followed by the opening of Nares Strait by deglaciation (8,400 years ago) and establishment of strong ASW inflow, to formation of the NOW ~ 5000 years ago as Holocene sea ice expanded. Modeling has provided context for the future of the NOW.

 

This project has succeeded in defining key events in the past configuration of the cryosphere resulting in two distinct and gateway openings of the western freshwater route between the Arctic Ocean and the North Atlantic. This sequence of events proceded in response to past climate change. It dramatically altered the paleoceanography in northern Baffin Bay and resulted in the development of the largest and most productive Arctic polynya with consequences for ecosystems and humans. Radiocarbon dating on the sediment cores has closely constrained the timing of these events so that modeling of their downstream impact can be explored. We think that by defining the events and their timing and the local consequences to marine productivity, the data provide better constrained paleo targets for directing model experiments of the consequences of future climate change. The modeling work has shown that the NOW is affected by anthropogenic climate change, and that staying below 2 °C of global warming is important to prevent a decrease in the biological activity in the NOW.

 

Broader impacts in terms of reaching communities outside of science include hands on activities for middle school students during open house tours at INSTAAR and laboratory visits by non science majors at CU. The benefit to human resource development includes undergraduate students employed in the laboratories and engaged in research including manuscript writing and professional meeting presentations, graduate student thesis projects and Post Doctoral researcher projects. Several papers have been published with students and early career first authorships and co-authorships.
